article.description: Earnest Shelton made five 3-pointers and scored 29 points to lead No. 19 Alabama over Minnesota 78-72 in the semifinals of the Great Alaska Shootout on Friday night.
article.headline: Shelton scores nine of Tide's last 15 points
article.linkText: Shelton's 29 lifts Alabama to Great Alaska final
article.story: ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) -- Alabama remained undefeated on the strength of their free-throw shooting -- and Minnesota's misses. The 19th-ranked Crimson Tide (3-0) made eight free throws in the final minute while the Golden Gophers were 5-for-9 in the last 3:49 as Alabama won 78-72 in the semifinals of the Great Alaska Shootout on Friday night. The Crimson Tide will take on Washington (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today, No. 22 AP) in the championship game after the Huskies beat Oklahoma 96-91. The Crimson Tide shot 30-for-36 from the line for the game. "If you're going to shoot like we did from the foul line, you always give yourself a chance to win," Alabama coach Mark Gottfried said. Earnest Shelton made five 3-pointers and scored 29 points to lead the Crimson Tide. He scored nine of Alabama's last 15 points to hold off a Golden Gophers second-half rally in which Minnesota (2-1) pulled within two at 70-68 with a minute left. "I felt like tonight it was one of those nights where I felt like I was going to score the ball or get fouled," Shelton said. "My teammates did a good job of getting the ball to me. Getting to the foul line, I stepped up and knocked them down." Gottfried said Minnesota's big men did a good job in the post. The Crimson Tide's Chuck Davis was held without a basket in the first half, which meant Alabama had to turn to its outside shooters. "I thought Earnest stepped up like a senior should," Gottfried said. Minnesota coach Dan Monson agreed that in the end, foul shooting made the difference. They made their free throws down the stretch and we didn't," Monson said. Kennedy Winston added 18 points and nine rebounds for the Crimson Tide, and Ronald Steele had 14 points. Dan Coleman led Minnesota with 16 points. Aaron Robinson added 14, Jeff Hagen had 12 and Vincent Grier 11. The Golden Gophers, who trailed 38-33 at halftime, came out strong in the second half as Coleman hit five jumpers in an eight-minute span to bring Minnesota within one at 52-51 with 12:01 to play. But the Golden Gophers could get no closer. Minnesota briefly led 25-23 on Robinson's 3-pointer in the first half, but Alabama went on a 12-1 run to close out the first half. Just three of Minnesota's players started the season with Division I experience, and it showed. "Our inexperience early in the game cost us as much as anything," Monson said. The Gophers missed 11 layups. "You can't fall behind against a quality team," Monson said. Alabama outrebounded Minnesota 37-29, led by Winston. Hagen had seven rebounds for the Golden Gophers.
